items.title: Simplexifying sustainability
Discovery of Roman and early medieval palisades in Grado (Italy) constraining relative sea level and paleoenvironment in the northern Adriatic Sea
items.body:
Download PDF

Article
    
        
            Open access

Published: 29 September 2025

Discovery of Roman and early medieval palisades in Grado (Italy) constraining relative sea level and paleoenvironment in the northern Adriatic Sea
                    Dario Gaddi1, Emiliano Gordini2, Emanuele Lodolo2, Federica Donda2, Daniele Melini3, Giorgio Spada4 & …Paola Ventura5 Show authors

Scientific Reports

volume 15, Article number: 33546 (2025)
            Cite this article

Subjects
        
            Climate-change impactsGeology

AbstractThe Roman settlements on the northern Adriatic provide evidence for the temporal fluctuations of relative sea level (RSL). The discovery of three buried palisades during an archaeological excavation in Grado (Italy), one of the most important Roman harbors, allowed us to reconstruct the position of the sea level on the northeastern Adriatic coast. Two of these wooden barriers provided the islanders with better access to the sea and more effective protection against coastal erosion. The oldest palisade (mid/end I–early II century AD) was intended to support the part of the artificial deposit closest to the shore and enabled the inhabitants access to it. Based on its position and a dated wood sample, which correlates with the chronology of the pottery, the RSL in the early imperial Roman age was -1.20 ± 0.30 m. The most recent palisade (VI century AD) shows a significant sea level rise of + 0.40 m RSL; it was probably built to compact part of the inundated soil and provided reinforcement in response to the sea level rise. The higher, but equally old palisade from the VI century AD, was probably built to consolidate the base of the Castrum of Grado. Based on these results, we add new data to reconstruct the RSL history of the northeastern Adriatic coast and delineate its environmental configuration, in which a lagoonal landscape developed shortly thereafter.

IntroductionThe history of the island of Grado is closely linked to two world-famous cities: Aquileia, one of the most important trading cities of the Roman Empire, and Venice. An old saying goes: “Grado is the daughter of Aquileia and the mother of Venice”, indeed. Probably the most ancient reference where the Grado island was cited is the “Historia Langobardorum” of Paulus Diaconus, dated back to 789 AD. The present-day physiography of the Grado island and its lagoon derives from a complex evolution which took place since the Last Glacial Maximum and the related sea level rise1. The first traces of the human presence in the Grado area date back to at least the II century BC, as revealed by a stratigraphic study, where 12 m of sediments were cored in the churchyard of the early Christian “Sant’Eufemia basilica”2, revealing the occurrence of fragments of ceramic artefacts between -1.6 and ca. -6 m below mean sea level (b.m.s.l.). Our remnants date back between the I century BC and the I century AD, and suggested the existence of a port or of other coastal anthropic activities probably linked to the newly formed Roman colony of Aquileia2. However, archaeological artifacts reveal that even before the Aquileia foundation (181 BC), the Grado area was inhabited, thanks to its proximity to the mouth of a navigable river (the palaeo-Isonzo3). The construction of residential buildings and the presence of a small necropolis4 signal a strong development of the settlement in the late imperial age5. However, the Grado’s main development stage took place when a new and different geopolitical context developed, following the siege of Aquileia by Attila (452 AD), the Greek Gothic war (535–553 AD) and the subsequent invasion of the Lombards (568 AD 6 and references therein). During the V and VI centuries AD, due to the recurring barbarian incursions, Grado became a fortress, and the Castrum, whose foundations are still in place, was built. Indeed, during the late Antiquity, Grado became a key port serving the whole north-eastern Italian area, instead of the Aquileia port that was suffering a decline phase, mostly due to hydrogeological changes, which led to the complete cover up of that port (7,8 and references therein).The geoarchaeological studies carried out in the Castrum and the archaeological finds discovered in the area led to the first estimates of the relative sea level (RSL), namely the change in sea level experienced at a specific location, in different periods: elevation measurements of Roman dwellings and early Christian monuments show that the sea level was lower than today since the construction of most ancient villas9. The Castrum walls have been set up on stilts within a predominantly water-saturated sandy subsoil, leading to hypothesize that the sea level at the VI century AD, i.e., when the Castrum was built, was ca. 1.32 to ca. 1.40 m lower than today, by taking also into account the tidal range. The tidal fluctuations on the northern Adriatic coast are microtidal (1 m), with the greatest amplitude occurring during the spring tide (average half-day difference of 0.86 m in the Gulf of Trieste and 1.0 m in Venice, with peaks of 1.30 up to 2.0 m) and the smallest amplitude recorded during the mean neap tide (daily differences of around 0.22 and 0.20 m in Trieste and Venice, respectively;10,11). Possible drivers of the change in sea level in the study area are the soil compaction (it was determined on site to be 0.35 mm/year for the period 1980–2000; 9), the regional subsidence (0.5 mm/yr12), and the sea level rise (1.23 mm/yr since 1890 as recorded by the Trieste tide gauge9). The above-mentioned factors allowed to estimate the relative sea level at 1 AD, which stood at ca. 1.70 m lower than today9. The occurrence of the Roman archaeological remnants known as “rovine di San Gottardo” and as “S. Agata” at water depths of ca. 4 m and 5 m b.m.s.l. respectively, 500 m far from the present-day coastline, and dated to the II-III centuries AD13, have been interpreted as structures pertaining to the Roman port14. These remnants provide further evidence that the Grado lagoon during the Roman period was mostly represented by emerged lands3.This paper presents the results of an archaeological investigation carried out in the close vicinity of the Castrum of Grado, where three containment palisades were identified among the various levels intercepted by the excavation. The dating of the woods that compose them and their quotes, refined by the analysis of the findings, has allowed a reconstruction of the relative sea level (RSL) between the I and VI centuries AD, together with a picture of the palaeogeographic environment of the Grado area during this period.Archaeological excavationThe intervention area is located a few meters from the inner port of Grado (Mandracchio port), built at the beginning of the XIX century, and 25 m to the east of the Castrum walls (Fig. 1).Fig. 1Location map of the study area. (A). The red star within the box indicates the location of Grado in the northern Adriatic coast. (B). Location of the archaeological investigation (red circle and arrow), with the perimeter of the Castrum (bold yellow line). Map data: Google, Image©2024 Airbus.Full size imageThe site was affected by a project to renovate the sewerage network, funded by Irisacqua (Gorizia), so the assessment of the archaeological impact was activated. In a preliminary phase, in 2017, several core drillings down to a maximum depth of ca. -3 m below the surface revealed the occurrence of worked wood, ceramic building material (CBM) and pottery remnants, the oldest ones dated back to the III-II centuries BC, thus highlighting the potential of the study area15.The open-area extensive excavation took place from January 29 to March 1, 2019 (ArcheoTest Srl, under the scientific direction of the Superintendence). The site was fortified with vertical iron barriers (sheet piles) embedded in the ground, and the soil was mechanically removed in areas without archaeological findings, and manually in correspondence to late antique and medieval epochs and Roman period structures and layers. The different stratigraphic units were labeled “US” followed by a number (Fig. 2).Fig. 2Plan view (A) and cumulative cross section (B) of the archaeological survey. US 1, 2: Landfill material of anthropogenic origin; US 3, 8, 9, 10: Sediments with widespread presence of fragments of earthenware; US 4: Ceramics, especially graffiti from the Renaissance and post-Renaissance period, majolica, earthenware, glass and building rubble in a lagoonal context; US 5: Increased humus content and presence of elements of anthropic origin, such as CBM and pottery fragments; US 6, 7: Silt/salt marsh – Lagoon deposits; US 11, 21: Mud lagoon plain with reed fragments; US 12: Clayey silt rich in pottery fragments and food remains derived from domestic waste and building rubble; US 13: Sandy silt rich in pottery fragments and mollusk shells; US 14: Bank palisade – Wooden beams; US 15: Stranded tree trunk; US 16, 17–23: Lagoon mudflat – velma; US 18, 20, 22: Series of deposits of building rubble and domestic waste, made by stones, CBM, different types of fragments, amphorae, glass vessels, animal bones and other food remains; US 19: Palisade—Vertically oak poles showing clear signs of Teredo navalis attack at the poles upper end; US 24: Planar, tidy arrangement of large round oval stones, with a small part of the skeleton consisting of pottery and shells; US 25: Sandy silty matrix and a skeleton of large stones, bricks, pottery and shells; US 26: Silty sand with shells, wood and charcoal fragments; US 27: Clayey silty layer with large fragments of amphorae flat arranged; US 28, 29: Deposits excavated to a very limited extent, which allowed the identification of a single fragment of pottery; US 30: Palisade—Oak, sessile oak and downy oak; US 31: Marine sand.Full size imageThe reference datum (height) commonly used in archaeological studies within the Castrum is the threshold of the “basilica of San Giovanni” in Grado, which corresponds to + 1.32 m above mean sea level9 measured by the tide gauge of Trieste.The deepest layer identified and documented during the new excavation is the relict of a lagoon mudflat, locally known as “velma” (US 16 = 23), which extends over the entire western part of the area at a depth of ca. -1 m b.m.s.l. (Fig. 2). It is an archaeologically sterile terrain that represents the dominant element of a context that has not yet been anthropized (Phase 1). The eastern boundary of this velma is formed by a thick deposit of marine sand (US 31); it is a yellowish-gray sand, with a petrographic composition indicating an origin from the Isonzo River basin16 containing fragments of different types of bivalvia, i.e., Cardiidae, Glycymeris sp., Ostrea edulis, together with needles of Abies alba and splinters of wood.The presence of a highly abraded Cerastoderma glaucum valve in this deposit necessarily reflects a high-energy environment. Its occurrence in relation to the Grado island and to the US 16 = 23 velma would indicate the presence of an open sea, an associated channel, or a break in the coastal barriers, similar to the present-day ones.Above the lagoon mudflat, the excavations have identified a series of deposits of building rubble and domestic waste, consisting of stones, CBM, fragments of common use and coarse ware, amphorae, glass vessels, animal bones and other food remains, belonging to US 12, 13, 18, 20, 22, 24, 25, 26 and 27 (Supplementary Figures S1, S2 and S3 related to US 13 and US 27). This material is most likely the result of a large and lengthy operation of draining and filling the soil of the coastal strip of the settlement of Grado, from the edge of the salt marsh towards the beach, to raise the level of walkway and make the soft and muddy ground firmer. Sedimentary strata become thicker towards the west, i.e., towards the elevated area of the future Castrum. This is the first anthropic settlement dated between the middle/end of the I and the beginning of the II century AD on the island of Grado that has been archaeologically proven and documented (Phase 2).These anthropic interventions also consist of a bank palisade (US 14), the top of which is at -0.60 m b.m.s.l., made of elongated alder planks with a rectangular cross-section and irregular dimensions, on average 15–20 cm wide and 8–10 cm thick; the longest planks are about 1 m long. The lower end of all the elements was sharpened with an ax to facilitate penetration into the ground (Fig. 3). The planks were laid with particular care to form a continuous barrier, with each element adjacent to the next one.Fig. 3The US 14 palisade. (A): the continuous barrier of the planks. (B): the planks sharpened by an ax to facilitate the penetration into the ground.Full size imageThe palisade has an almost rectilinear course with an approximately north–south orientation, i.e., parallel to the long side of the coastal dune on which the ancient settlement of Grado was built. The palisade extends both to the south and to the north beyond the limits of the excavation; its presence near the sheet piles could not be documented because it was necessary to create lower areas that would allow the isolation of a central area for carrying out the archaeological investigation. The upper end of the planks appears to be finished and not worn nor broken (aside from the elements damaged by the bulldozer bucket). This observation, combined with the absence of any traces of Teredo navalis (Linnaeus, 1758) attack and the excellent state of preservation of the timber, suggests that the planks were placed at the edge of the bank in an area largely above the water to create a barrier to material removed from the mainland. As widely known, Teredo navalis is a xylophagous microorganism that is widespread in the Mediterranean Sea. It can survive on a wooden diet only, unlike other shipworm, and can withstand unfavorable conditions like exposure to air or freshwater for about three weeks17. If the wood is covered, it will not be degraded by woodborers due to limited dissolved oxygen in the water which prevents their respiration18. Due to the fact that Teredo navalis reproduces exclusively in permanently submerged wood that may be exposed to air for short periods of time, this element can be considered as a sea level indicator. On piles anchored in the seabed, it can occupy a band that extends from the seabed to mean sea level; its presence on a pile indicates an area that once emerged from the seabed but was permanently or almost permanently below mean sea level.Moreover, during the Phase 2, in the western part of the excavation, starting from the bottom there is a layer of silty sand with shells, wood and charcoal fragments (US 26), located at ca. -1.5 m b.m.s.l. and interpreted as the first human intervention to reclaim the area on the surface of the original lagoon floor. Micropalaeontology analyses on a sample taken from US 26 indicate the occurrence of an open lagoon, with a good sea water exchange. Above of US 26, a pseudo-horizontal layer with sandy silt matrix and a skeleton of large stones, bricks, pottery and shells occurs (US 25). Above it, a clayey silt layer with large fragments of amphorae flat arranged (US 27); micropalaeontological analyses on a sample taken from this stratigraphic unit reveal the occurrence of an intertidal environment located close to a salt marsh. Along the edge of the excavated section, a layer was identified with a planar, tidy arrangement of large round oval stones, with the smaller components consisting of pottery and shells (US 24).Above the velma, only a layer of sandy silt rich in pottery fragments and mollusk shells is reported (US 13) along both sides of the palisade: the sediment matrix is referrable to an internal lagoonal environment, possibly represented by sub-tidal sediments, excavated from the lagoon floor to rise the site.To the east of US 14, a layer of distinctly clayey silt containing a large quantity of pottery fragments and food remains derived from domestic waste and building rubble characterizes US 12. A large tree trunk (perhaps a maritime pine judging by the bark) lying parallel to the palisade US 14 at the eastern boundary of US 12 and in close proximity to the US 31 sandy deposit, indicating that it is a stranded tree trunk, has been found at ca. -1 m b.m.s.l. (US 15, Fig. 4 A and B). We argue that the trunk was transported in a N-S direction during a high-energy event, namely a sea storm, possibly associated with strong northerly winds (scirocco or libeccio) and high tides. Such conditions are common in the study area, especially in the fall and spring, when trunks similar to that found during our archeological excavation are thrown onto the beaches of Grado and its surroundings (Fig. 4 C).Fig. 4A, B: The stranded tree trunk (US 15). (A): Aerial view; (B): N-S view; (C): trunk stranded on an island east of Grado in spring 2025.Full size imageThe excavations have thus shown the presence of an artificial arrangement of the shore with the building of the palisade US 14 and the creation of a “sherd beach”, which represents a kind of “artificial extension” of the II century AD shoreline, and consists of pottery fragments, that lie flat and are iso-oriented. Based on this arrangement of the archeological finds, we argue that it is an artificial landfill that acts like a beach, where the action of the seawater aligned the ceramic fragments according to the line of least resistance. It was followed (Phase 3) by the formation of a new lagoon plain (US 11), covering both the artificial deposits US 12 and 13 as well as the trunk US 15 and the palisade US 14. US 11—a small part of which identified as US 21—can also be found in the western area. It is characterized by the presence of reed fragments that supports its identification as a salt marsh. Despite of the very scarce archaeological findings, this phase can be dated between the III-V/mid VI centuries AD.Afterwards (Phase 4), a massive bank reinforcement was created, i.e., the US 19 palisade, by driving long oak piles vertically into the ground (Fig. 5). The upper edge of this palisade is at -0.85 m b.m.s.l. From a stratigraphic point of view, the intrusion of US 19 certainly took place after the deposition of US 18, 20, 21, 22, 24, 25, 26, 27, which it crosses: the piles have strongly disturbed these layers by displacing large stones and CBM, mixing the sediments and pulling the smaller elements downwards.Fig. 5The palisades US 19 and US 30. (A). The upper termination of palisade US 19 (in the foreground) and of palisade US 30 (in the background); (B): Teredo navalis on the poles of the US 19 palisade.Full size imageThe oak trunks have a diameter of at least 20 cm and were divided into radial sectors with a sub-triangular cross-section. Only the lower part of the poles remains, which is sharpened at the end by ax cuts to a maximum length of 110 cm. The piles show clear signs of infestation at their upper ends by Teredo navalis.In contrast to US 14, this is not a continuous palisade, but a system of poles arranged in a band about 50 cm long, in which, in addition to most of the poles lying next to each other, there are also elements lying further forward or back. Anyway, it is aligned roughly north–south and, like US 14, follows the course of the eastern edge of the Castrum of Grado.The last human intervention of the ancient period is also testified by a third palisade, US 30 (Fig. 5), of which only three posts remain; the identified wood species is deciduous oak (Quercus sp.), which includes common oak, sessile oak and downy oak, anatomically very similar species that are difficult to distinguish. The poles were fixed in US 28, 29: they were all discovered near the western edge of the sheet pile wall and were only excavated to a very limited extent, which allowed the identification of a single fragment of pottery. The palisade US 30 is located on a higher level and probably had a different function than US 19, related to the consolidation of the Castrum and therefore did not serve as protection against sea ingression.No surfaces or fills have survived from the early medieval occupation phase (Phase 5), although the palisades US 19 and US 30 were certainly still in use, associated with occupation levels outside the site, probably located further west near the walls of the Castrum of Grado. The area where the piles were driven was gradually filled in after the mid-VI century AD by a deposit of lagoonal sediments, US 6 and—overall—US 7, which is about 1 m thick and resulted in a large silt/salt marsh that apparently occupies the entire study area. The salt marsh does not appear to have been constantly frequented over time, and only in the upper part, immediately below US 5, some stones and small brick fragments have been found. The great thickness of the lagoon deposit and its position within the stratigraphic sequence allowed us to associate this phase with the middle Age, for which we have neither information nor archaeological data reliably related to the frequentation of the site.US 5 marks the beginning of a new period of occupation of the area (Phase 6), with the appearance of deposits in which both the humus content and the presence of elements of anthropic origin, such as CBM and pottery fragments, gradually increase. It still seems to be a sporadic presence linked to a peripheral area, perhaps related to the opening of a new gate on the western side of the walls, in correspondence with the current area of “Porta Nuova”, which, together with the name, still preserves the remains of the ancient tower integrated into the modern buildings. Even in the absence of specific studies, it is possible to confirm a Renaissance origin for the construction of the gate that was first depicted in a map dating back to 1509 19. US 5, together with US 4, shows an intensification of components of artificial origin, ceramics, especially graffiti from the Renaissance and post-Renaissance period, majolica, earthenware, glass and building rubble, in a context that always comes from the lagoon and testifies to a long-lasting occasional frequentation.The most recent layers of stratification, US 8, 9, 3, 10 (Phase 7) are more consistent and the widespread presence of fragments of earthenware allows us to date them between the end of the XVIII century and the beginning of the XIX century (Fig. 6).Fig. 6Schematic reconstruction of the different evolution phases for the study area. Circled numbers (in yellow) indicate the stratigraphic units, numbers in blue squares indicate the palisades. S: surface; G: ground.Full size imageAge of the palisadesThree elements of palisade US 14 were dated by measuring carbon-14 isotopes (Table 1; samples GRA19 PMI P1, GRA19 PMI P2, GRA19 PMI P3). Although the extremes of the proposed dating cover a very wide chronological range, the stratigraphic position of the palisade in phase with the archaeological deposits US 12 and US 13 allows to reduce the age range and to date construction period of the oldest palisade, which dates back to the middle/end of the I and the beginning of the II century AD.Table 1 Calibrated age of the wooden samples taken from the palisades US 14, US 19 and US 30.Full size tableAs already mentioned, from a stratigraphic point of view, the embedding of palisade US 19 certainly occurs after the deposition of the US 18, 20, 21, 22, 24, 25, 26, 27 drainages, which it crosses. This observation is confirmed by the results of dating using the radiocarbon method (Table 1; samples GRA19 PMI P4, GRA19 PMI P5; GRA19 PMI P6). Moreover, this palisade is more precisely dated compared to the oldest one thanks to dendrochronology (see Methods), which gives an age of 566 AD. The US 19 palisade is then a much later intervention than the construction of the first palisade and the associated “sherd beach”.Concerning the palisade US 30, only one sample has been dated through 14C (Table 1). No further dating has been performed on palisade US 30, due to the fact the poles utilized to build that palisade derived from young stems with very short annular sequences, so that they are not suitable for dendrochronology. The calibrated range shows that the very wide chronological range is almost identical to that obtained from sample GRA19 PMI P6 taken from US 19, which allows us to consider palisades US 19 and US 30 as contemporaneous.DiscussionThe collected data allow to reconstruct a palaeoenvironment context for the study area in which the eastern side of the barrier island of Grado opened into a lagoon area surrounded by a beach. The area was artificially structured by the construction of a wooden barrier (palisade) and the dumping of building rubble and domestic waste, which formed a “sherd beach” that gave the inhabitants of the island better access to the sea and probably more effective protection against marine ingression. To our knowledge, there are no similar examples of artificial beaches, at least in the Mediterranean area. Further archaeological and environmental investigations are therefore required to substantiate our hypothesis. The palisade probably had the function of holding the part of the artificial mound closest to the shore and allowing the part of the shore facing the sea to be walked on without sinking. A similar wooden structure, dated to the beginning of the II century AD, was discovered on one of the lagoon islands of Grado. However, its quadrangular shape and the discovery of 200 almost intact amphorae led archaeologists to believe that it was a cellar and not an enclosure palisade20, like the palisades we describe here.It is well known that the elevations of archaeological structures near the shoreline (harbor piers, fishtanks and fishponds, slipways, coastal quarries, sewerslides, etc.) can be used to define the ancient coastlines where the site was built and in particular to determine the sea level in the past. The long history of human occupation in the Mediterranean has left an abundance of archaeological evidence along its shores, and these structures are widely recognized as important markers for reconstructing past sea levels21,22 and have been used to estimate sea-level index points (SLIPs). These indicators are described according to a recently developed standard protocol (Hjima et al., 2015), in which: (i) the location of the indicator, (ii) the calibrated age of the indicator, and (iii) the elevation of the indicator with respect to a specific datum (i.e., the elevation with respect to the mean sea level) are precisely determined. Each index point is described by its indicative range, which corresponds to the height interval in which the index point could have formed. However, the determination of SLIPs involves several potential sources of error that can affect the accuracy of sea level reconstructions. These can arise from a number of factors, such as dating uncertainties, post-depositional changes, misinterpretation of indicator relationships, geophysical factors, etc. Once the residual elevations of the archaeological remains are defined in relation to the sea at that time, the palaeo sea level is compared with the present one and the resulting difference is used to quantify the local sea level change from the historical period to the present. According to Shennan and Horton23, RSL is hence estimated using the following equation: RSL = (E − I) ± V, where E is the measured elevation of the feature, I is the indicative meaning (the tidal level associated with the feature’s function) and V is the vertical uncertainty. This procedure has been widely applied in various contexts on the Italian coasts and in the western Mediterranean to constrain the relative sea level of the past24, also for pre-Roman times and in particular for the Bronze Age in the northern Adriatic25.Wooden palisades that preserve biological markers and/or are associated to specific sedimentary records, as those descripted in this work, can serve as indicators to estimate former sea levels. Lagoonal sediments provide ideal conditions for preserving wooden structures by reducing oxygen availability, preventing microbial decay, limiting physical erosion, and protecting the wood with sediment layers. This makes them an excellent environment for archaeological reconstructions. The presence of Roman wooden structures, dated and preserved because they are submerged, is remarkable. For the easternmost palisade, the US 14, radiocarbon measurements indicate a date range between the middle of the II century BC and the III century AD (Table 1). The pottery deposits in the associated layers allow to reduce this age range between the middle/end of the I century AD and the early II century AD. As these are deposits consisting of household waste and production remains, it can be assumed that they originate from deposits that formed over a period of several years but were piled up along the shore at the same time as the construction of the wooden barrier US 14 to form the beach. According to these findings, we hence consider the age of 100 AD a reliable value for the relative sea level curves calculation, with a reasonable uncertainty of ± 30 years. Near beach US 31, on US 26, in an open lagoon with good seawater exchange, a few dozen meters from the coast of the barrier island of Grado, an intervention was thus carried out to raise and consolidate the banks to facilitate access to the channel. The morphology of the lagoon bottom, on which the layers containing the archaeological material were poured, is not flat, but has a depression corresponding to the area of layers US 26, 25, 27, and 24. The head of the palisade US 14 protrudes a few centimeters from the surface of US 16 and serves to contain the layers dumped between the palisade and the island of Grado, while the material to the east, represented by US 12, only serves to consolidate the bed near the channel US 31 (Fig. 6).The presence of a stranded log resting at the level of -0.90 m b.m.s.l., the intact head of the planks of US 14 (-0.60 m b.m.s.l.) not attacked by the Teredo navalis, and the fact that the sand of US 31 (-0.90 m b.m.s.l.) indicates an environment only occasionally flooded, are the elements that we have taken into account for the calculation of the RSL at this site. We measured the elevation of the head of the palisade (E = -0.6 m below the present mean sea level), and because this palisade represents a coastal defense on a lagoonal beach, it likely correlates with high tide or slightly above, so we assume its indicative meaning (I) at this site of + 0.6 m relative to the mean sea level. Applying the formula RSL = E-I, we obtain -1.2 m. In our case, the total vertical uncertainty (i.e., the uncertainty on the reconstructed past sea level) derives from two main components: e1 (± 0.05 m), which refers to the measured elevation error (e.g., due to GPS surveying); e2 (± 0.30 m), which reflects the uncertainty associated with the indicative meaning (e.g., the tidal zone at which the indicator functioned). The root-mean-square formula: etotal = (e21 + e22)1/2 yields a value of ≈0.30 m. Therefore, the total vertical uncertainty for this SLIP, which accounts for variability of tidal conditions, storm surges, and construction height, is estimated at ± 0.3 m. Palisade US 19, which is dated to the year 566 AD and was severely attacked by the Teredo navalis, indicates a considerable rise in mean sea level. The Teredo navalis of US 19 occupies a strip of a few centimeters in correspondence with the preserved top of the poles, at a level between -0.80 and -0.90 m b.m.s.l. Taking into account a tidal range similar to that of today, the application of the RSL formula yields a value of -0.80 m at the VI century. The total vertical uncertainty for this SLIP is analogous to the previous SLIP (± 0.30 m). This rise in mean sea level, which should also be evaluated in the context of subsidence phenomena, could be a contributory cause of the nature of the matrix of the layers of US 26 to US 18, typical of submerged lagoon environments, whose artificial component would have been discharged between the I and II centuries AD, whereas the matrix at the time of the rise in mean sea level was between the II and VI centuries AD. The palisades US 19 and US 30 appear to represent a structural intervention of a different kind than the palisade US 14. The piles heaped up from above compact a ca. 50 cm wide strip under the water and could represent a later intervention to stabilize the bank than the one from the middle/end of the II century AD.These two index points are plotted as calibrated age against change in sea level relative to present (Fig. 7). The figure also shows a post-glacial RSL curve obtained by solving the “Sea Level Equation” (SLE; 26, describing the spatio-temporal variations in sea level associated with the progressive melting of the late Pleistocene ice sheets. No contributions from tectonic subsidence, compaction of sediments and other relevant geological processes were considered. We solved numerically the SLE by means of the open-source SELEN4 code27,28, which includes the effects of rotational feedback on sea level according to the revised theory of Mitrovica et al.29 and accounts for horizontal migration of shorelines and variations of the ocean function following the method outlined by Peltier30. Here we have assumed an evolution of the ice sheets according to the ICE-5G model of Peltier30, in agreement with Vacchi et al.24. The dashed line in Fig. 7 represents the RSL curve obtained with the original VM2 viscosity profile, while the solid line and the blue shaded region represent, respectively, the RSL curve according to the nominal three-layer approximation of VM2 used in Vacchi et al.24 and the range of RSL variation estimated through a mini-ensemble of 27 rheological profiles obtained by exploring different values for the lithospheric thickness and upper and lower mantle viscosities (see Table 2 in24).Fig. 7Relative sea level curves. Curves derive from the ICE-5G model using the VM2 viscosity profile (dashed line) and the nominal three-layer approximation used by Vacchi et al.24 (solid line). The shaded area represents the range of variation of RSL estimated with the mini-ensemble approach followed by Vacchi et al.24. The two index points of the palisades US 14 and US 19 are plotted as calibrated age against change in sea level relative to the present, with errors in depth (bars) and age (for US 14).Full size imageTable 2 Occurrence (%) of benthic foraminifera in the analyzed samples.Full size tablePrevious studies have attempted to reconstruct the ancient sea level in the Grado lagoon area on the basis of archaeological and geomorphological information. An estimate of the sea level around the IV century AD derived from the heights of the most important early Christian monuments of Grado and taking into account the effects of soil compaction and subsidence, yielded a value of -1.4 m compared to the current mean sea level9. That sea level is related to the reference height of the national altimetric network of Italy represented by the tidal gauge of Genova, which is higher than that of Trieste (where there is one of the longest records in the national context, starting in 1890) of 0.05 m. Studies have shown that rates of Holocene subsidence in the northern Adriatic coast are quite variable, ranging from ca. 0.7 mm/yr in the Venetian plain to ca. 0.4 mm/yr in the eastern part of the Friuli coast31. To the east in the Gulf of Trieste, along the rocky coastline of the Karst, there are significant geomorphological traces of submerged notches (Duino) at a depth of -1.7 ± 0.2 m, and also flooded harbor facilities at a depth of 1.2–1.5 m below sea level (Muggia), indicating in this case a significant tectonic component32. Along this stretch of coast, subsidence rates vary from -1.99 mm/yr to 1.01 mm/yr.ConclusionsThis multidisciplinary study documents the discovery of three Roman palisades dated at middle/end I–early II and VI centuries AD in Grado, one of the main sites connected to the port system of Aquileia, among the most important in Roman times, and its implication for the RSL reconstruction at that times. Two of these palisades were used to protect and consolidate the land immediately in front of the open sea, or of a channel or a lagoon mouth, supporting the part of the artificial deposit closest to the shore and allowing the inhabitants to access the shore without sinking when the sea level rose. The construction of wooden barriers and the dumping of building rubble and domestic waste created a “shard beach”, which provided the islanders, in addition to better access to the sea, probably also a more effective protection against coastal erosion. The terminal parts of these palisades measured in reference to the mean sea level, and the radiocarbon dating carried out on wooden fragments of the same handworks, were used as index points to constrain the position of the sea level in the I and VI centuries AD on the northeastern Adriatic coast. The outcomes of these analyses led us to establish that the sea level was -1.20 ± 0.50 m in the middle/end I–early II century AD and rose by about + 0.40 m by the VI century AD. The stratigraphic analysis of the strata intercepted by the excavation and the sedimentological characteristics of the various depositional sequences have also enabled us to add key information on the palaeoenvironmental framework for the Grado area as it appeared in the Roman and medieval period and to outline a scheme for the variations in sea level in this sector of the northern Adriatic (Fig. 8).Fig. 8Schematic reconstruction of the study area in the two periods related to the discovered palisades (circled numbers).Full size imageWe hypothesize that the settlement core was located in a coastal strip facing the open sea, or along a channel connecting the inner tidal area with the open sea, similar to today’s lagoon environment. This means that the Grado and the neighboring Marano lagoon are the most recent representatives of a series of coastal environments with shallow seas surrounded by sandy beaches and tidal flats that have characterized the coastal landscape of the northern Adriatic from south to north since the end of the Last Glacial Maximum, and have been gradually buried as a result of sea level rise.MethodsDendrochronological investigations and species identifications on the wooden remainsSeven wooden samples, represented by 5 cm-thick cross sections taken from US 14, 19 and 30 palisades, have been analyzed by Nicoletta Martinelli at the Dendrodata Laboratory (Verona, Italy). After the identification of the wooden species on autopsy-based analysis, an evaluation of the length of the annular series has been performed, and 3 samples have been selected for the dendrochronological analyses, addressed to providing an absolute date of these remains.Wood analyses have been conducted on the cross sections taken from the wooden samples through an optical microscope. The identification of the wooden species has been made following33,34,35,36,37. The samples are represented by hardwoods: palisade US 14 is made by Alnus glutinosa/incana, whereas US 19 and US 30 by deciduous oak of the ROBUR section.The dendrochronological investigations were carried out on samples taken from the palisade US 19, according to the classic procedures described by Baillie and Fritts38,39. The thickness of the growth rings was determined with the Lintab instrument by F. Rinn (Heidelberg, Germany), which allows precision to the hundredth of millimeter. The collected data were recorded and processed with the Catras© (Computer Aided Tree Ring Analysis) and TSAP© (Time Series Analysis Program - TSAP-WinTM2003) programs. The three deciduous oak wood samples analyzed were selected both for the wood species (ROBUR), particularly suitable for dendrochronological investigations, and for the annular sequence exceeding 40 rings in length; they consist of a sub-triangular cross section obtained from oak trunks with a diameter of at least 20 cm, divided into radial sectors. Concerning the absolute dendrochronological dating, since the construction of a standard oak curve for the northern Italy region is still missing40, a teleconnection with the two foreign chronologies of the oak tree for central-western Germany (700 BC-1964 AD) and for central-southern Germany (7237 BC-1963 AD;41) has been tentatively used. By taking into account the information derived by the radiocarbon determinations (see below), the cross-dating was conducted against the regional oak chronology elaborated for the Veneto region (Martinelli, 2019), dated through wiggle-matching. The outcomes of these analyses provide a possible absolute dating of the last ring of the average curve obtained from the poles to 565 cal AD (± 21 years). Since the average curve lacks the cambial ring the felling of the oak stems should be traced back to the summer of 566 cal AD.Radiocarbon datingRadiocarbon dating has been performed by the Centro di Datazione Diagnostica - CEDAD (Università del Salento, Italy) on seven samples, three of them taken from palisade US 19, through a high-resolution mass spectrometry (AMS). The extracted material was subsequently converted into carbon dioxide by combustion at 900 °C in an oxidizing environment, and then in graphite by means of reduction. H2 was used as the reducing element and iron powder as catalyst. The radiocarbon concentration was determined by comparing the measured values 12C and 13C currents, and 14C counts with values obtained from samples Sucrose C6 standards provided by the IAEA. Conventional radiocarbon dating has been corrected for the effects of isotopic fractionation and by directly measuring the δ13C term with the accelerator, both for the bottom of the measurement. Samples of known concentration of Oxalic Acid provided by NIST (National Institute of Standards and Technology) were used as quality control of results. For the determination of the experimental error in the radiocarbon data, both the scattering of the data around the mean value and the statistical error resulting from the 14C count have been taken into account. Radiocarbon dating was then calibrated in calendar age using OxCal Ver. 4.4 software based on atmospheric data42, which provides the age of the four samples taken from palisade US 19, from the second half of the III and the second half of the V century AD, which are consistent with those obtained from dendrochronology: 566 ± 21 AD.ArchaeomalacologyArchaeomalacology analyses have been perfomed by the Laboratorio di Archeobiologia dei Musei Civici di Como, ARCO—Cooperativa di Ricerche Archeobiologiche (Italy) on samples taken from US 13, US 24, US 25, US 26 and US 31 levels, which reveal the occurrence of 716 findings, belonging to three main environments: terrestrial, marine, in which most of the findings, represented by gastropod and bivalve molluscs occur, and freshwater. However, marine molluscs have more robust shells than the terrestrial ones, characterized by thinner and therefore more fragile niches. Concerning the terrestrial environment, in US 13 and US 24, together with the malacological material, 7 bone fragments were found. In US 13 they consist of indeterminable charred bone fragments referred to a medium-sized mammal, and of micromammal scapula, suggesting they are meal remains, and the remains of a mouse, respectively. In US 24, an incisor of a rodent micromammal and an indeterminable mammalian bone fragment were found. All these findings, which comprise Cochlicella barbara, Trochoidea trochoides, Candidula unifasciata, which live in coastal, sandy and dry zones, indicate that their accumulation occurred in situ, following the death of the specimens due to natural causes. 655 findings belong to the marine environment, and all the analyzed stratigraphic units contain marine organisms. They can be subdivided in three main groups: species accumulated in situ, following the natural death of organisms, such as Bittium scabrum, Nassarius pygmaeus, Retusa candidula; species transported by waves, species fished by man for various purposes, Cerastoderma edule, Ostrea edulis, Venus nux vive, Abra alba. Concerning the freshwater environment, 27 findings occurred within US 24, and are represented by specimens, such as Theodoxus fluviatilis, Mercuria similis, Hidrobidae, that died either in situ or in close proximity, and indicate the occurrence of fluvial deltas and brackish ponds. In summary, archaeomalacology suggest that the palaeoenvironment was characterized by dunes and beaches that include a marine benthic domain, but also terrestrial and freshwater habitats, such river deltas at the interface between the marine and the terrestrial environment. The action of wave motion, storm surges and river floods allow for the input of various organic materials, particularly near the mouths of large rivers.Sedimentological and micropalaeontological analysesSedimentological and micropalaeontological analyses have been performed by the Dipartimento di Geoscience (Università di Padova, Italy) and by the Istituto di Geoscienze e Georisorse CNR-IGG, respectively on seven samples taken from US 13, US 22, US 24, US 25, US 27, US 26, US 31. They mostly consist of fill deposits carried out in ancient times or sediments heavily reworked by anthropic activities, as the description of the excavation phases already reported. Based on that, an accurate sedimentological analysis has been performed only for sample taken from US 31, which corresponds to a sand deposit located to the east of the archaeological investigations, and for the matrix of US 26 and 27, which are in place. The natural depositional sequence underlying the archaeological units can be interpreted as a typical sedimentary succession generated by a marine transgression above an alluvial plain. Over the last few thousands of years the area appears to have been characterized by a lagoon-type environment which testifies that the area being excavated was lying in the landward sector of the barrier island on which Grado rises. The sample taken from US 31 was treated in water and freed of the fraction smaller than 63 microns in order to obtain only grains of sand (0.063–2 mm). The sand was thus quartered with a splitter until obtaining a fraction of approximately 2 cm high in a cylindrical container with a diameter of 3 cm. This fraction was therefore incorporated in two-component resin (Araldite, 2020) in order to obtain a block of artificial rock. After drying in the oven, the resulting tablet was then treated as a slice of rock from which the thin section was obtained for investigation under the microscope. The thin section was stained with alizarin red, in order to quickly distinguish the grains of calcium carbonate, which turn pink in a few seconds, from the dolomitic ones which remain colorless if exposed to the solution for a few seconds. The sample is constituted by very fine silty (> 25–30%), yellowish gray (2.5Y 6/2–3) sands (90–150 μm), with rare fragments of wood, perhaps identifiable as portions of roots, and exogenous clasts. The latter are millimetric in size, but an abraded Cerastoderma glaucum valve has been also found, possibly indicating the transport and movement of the sands. Based on microscopic observations, the sample has a lithic composition dominated by fragments of carbonate rocks (limestone and dolomitic) and rare clasts of flint, quartz, bioclasts, foraminifera and carbonaceous phyllosilicates. Limestone clasts are usually more abundant than the dolomite ones.Micropalaeontological analyses have been carried out in six samples. Samples were prepared according to standard procedures for the analysis of benthic foraminifera: they were washed with water on a 0.063 mm mesh sieve to disperse the pelitic fraction and were dried in an oven at 50 °C. For the micropalaeontological analysis, the residue > 0.125 mm, generally observed and analyzed in lagoon environments analogous43, has been analyzed. For each sample, a suitable fraction of sediment was quickly analyzed to evaluate the composition of the benthic Foraminifera association in marginal marine environments where specific diversity is very low, like in the study area. The classification of the Foraminifera followed the taxonomy of Loeblich and Tappan44. The organogenic part is made up of benthic Foraminifera, Ostracods, bioclasts and biosomes of Molluscs, opercula of freshwater gastropods and plant remains. The fraction greater than 0.500 mm of all samples contain, to varying degrees, plant remains and small fragments carbonised, lithic fragments with different degrees of rounding. Some samples contain fragments of terracotta, brick or glass, as well as bioclasts of marine molluscs. Samples contain an association of foraminifera compatible with a temperate lagoon environment similar to the present-day northern Adriatic lagoons. In particular, the association occurring in sample 2 (US 13, see Table 2) can be related to the internal lagoon biotope (Inner Lagoon Biotope) described in the Venice Lagoon43, indicating a subtidal lagoon environment with a fairly high degree of confinement. The association present in samples 4 (US 24), 5 (US 25) and 7 (US 26, see Table 2) can refer to the outer lagoon biotope of the Venice Lagoon, related to a subtidal lagoon environment with a good exchange of sea water. The association present in sample 6 (US 27, see Table 2) can instead refer to the biotope near the salt marsh (near-marsh biotope) of the Venice Lagoon, indicating an intertidal environment with an average elevation below sea level, and located near a salt marsh. Samples 2 (US 13) and 3 (US 22) indicate a more internal lagoon environment.
